is from Auburn, New Hampshire has been out from the beginning of the war— has been was wounded five months ago—has just returned from a furlough of 30 days home.—gave him a jar of spiced apple preserve. very nice—a quiet good young man—much deprestdepressed in spirits
J. V. Read, co H. 155th Penn.

Feb. 18. just come in from Windmill Pt. last Saturday night—has been was there a month—typhoid fever, when for some time flighty. very sick, a gentle lad, in his 20th year—folks in Rimersburg Clarion co. Penn—father & mother there—father a tanner—lost a brother in this war killed in the 7 days fight before Richmond—seems to have joined the army from a genuine sense of duty—gave him some money—also some paper, envelopes &c

pneumonia—lay sick at Windmill point, about a week—came down there to help, had charge of one tent as nurse—and fell sick himself—is a widower, with children—gave him the tea, (I saw it made strong for him Feb. 12th —the doctor said it would be good for him)—is a strong ru gristly, hard, style of man—pretty sick—poor fellow—gave the 225 cts. Feb 12th—said he had no great use for mon but should use it for milk

div1.p: Called to‑day about 1 p.m. upon Preston King—he did not know me, and said candidly he could not do any thing in the way of getting me a place—did not at first remember that Mr. Sumner had spoken to him about me—but at last had an a vague recollection of something. King was blunt, decisive and manly—(said he could not endorse me—how did he know but what I was a secessionist?) My impression of King was good. I think Sumner is a sort of ggelding—no good.

Went with Mrs. O'Connor a while in the Senate gallery—then we went into the Supreme Court room (old Senate Chamber)—saw TChief Justice Taney and all the other black gowned Supreme Judges—their forms and faces good fit them old, and wrinkled, heavy—a lot of old mummies.

div1.ab: —aWent also into the Congressional library—a splendid view from the high colonnade in front of it. Then went off into the rich chamber, for the meetings of the Agricultural committee of the Representatives—a magic, painted, marble rich‑hued palace room.—Also into the H. of R. session—the interior work of the new capitol impresses me more and more with its richness beauty and perfect manipulation.

div2.ab: gangrene of feet, pretty bad—will have to lose three toes—(a regular hearty country boy.)

Case in Ward H—swelled face, fearfully distorted and out of all proportion.—scrofula—poor boy lies with all the time uttering a sort of groaning purr purring sound, pitiful to hear—very indicating gr different from any thing I had before heard sick—got well and got his discharge—but spoilt his stomach and blood with pastry &c in excess—

div1.head: The crow
div1.p: The crow plays (to a shrewd, upward‑looking observer) quite a part in the Washington landscape. You see them flying in plentiful straggling lines, in a west by northwest direction, thousands and thousands of them, over the city at this season of the year. You can hardly look out indeed, over the capital, or any where, especially by the Potomac, without seeing one or more, steadily flapping along, up above there, and sometimes flying quite low.

div1.ab: scene of the Catholic priest administering the extreme unction to a patient poor dying, an Irish boy not expected to live.
Went in to see a few particular patient soldiers in Armory Square, in Ward I. This is the gloomiest ward in the Ho any Hospital I have visited—amusements are prohibited by the

div1.p: Had an interview this morning with Preston King, in a room in rear of Capitol, (gorgeous fresco ornamentations on ceiling)—he made a good impression on me—with him there was a lady, middle-aged, drest in black—also a garrulous Irish soldier—he attended to their cases, and then to me—talked quite freely—gave me a letter to the Secretary of the Treasury—also to Gen'l Meigs, Chief of Quartermaster dep't—(met Lucien Cole, first rode up walked around together a little, rode up in cars—he got out with me—his parents live in Washington—he is a miller, works somewhere in a flour mill between here and Baltimore)

div1.ab: Spent a large part of the day in Armory Sq. Hospital—say saw Johnny Mackay. Ward E. in one of his spasms of pain——in ward F. gave money for the third time to a young man this afternoon Jut Boyd come up and took dinner with Mr & Mrs OConnor and me—he went back to the hospital at dark
was down at office 15th & T. writing most of the day.

div1.p:
I write this just at sundown in the high 5th floor room, Paymaster's office, cor 15th & F. Washington—it is a most beautiful sunset, clearing up bright & golden after a cloudy wet day.—I never saw any thing more beautiful than the scene around Washington— the sun dazzling in gold, is just set over Arlington heights—the lordly Potomac spreads, reflecting the evening clouds—the great white Capitol, with its great huge, pope's‑tiara‑looking dome lifts itself calmly on Capitol hill with windows gilded by the setting sun's day's last yellow‑reddishhalo—the
dark bro sombrre brown Smithsonian stands there, as with the shadows growing rapidly deeper around it—the —the the Patent Office, its severe and grand proportions show well, as they catch the last flood of light, the day vouchsafes—the mists and darkness grow heavier and heavier over there on the Maryland side—I see to toward the north the long white barracks of clusters of hospitals——also the soldiers home——southward I see the smoke of a single steamer crawling just gliding moving up crawling the Potomac this side the bridge———I see the grayish white of the
half-carried up monument to the noblest of Americans—see onthe spots of forts and camps on the hills above the river on the Virginia side—see the clear bright transparent copper‑colored clouds hang up there, gradually fading—sweep my eyes in admiration around the unsurpassed and broad‑stretched environ‑scenery of river, hill, and wood, that makes this one of the most beautiful beauteous natural locations on the continent—? over
—A long string of army wagons are defiling along 15th st, and around into Pennsylvania avenue—the white canvas coverings arch them over, and six mules draw each each one has its six-mule team—the teamsters are some of them walking along by the sides of their animals—a squads of the provost‑guard are passing tramping frequently along——and once or twice a party of cavalry in their yellow-trimmed jackets pro gallopsping along—
I see sick and wounded
soldiers, (but that's nothing now—I have seen so many thousands of them)—the light falls, falls, touches the cold white of the great public efices edifices—touches with a kind of death‑glaze here and there the windows of Washington—first lingesrs on the gilt balls and crosses on the steeples——theI see the street‑lamps beginning to be touched up, like bright sparks in the distance— a bell from some church begins to toll with mournful musical sound f—and I close

div1.p:
What a change from yesterday—Now there is a thick snow falling,—the s it commenced before day‑light, and is quite deep—no wind so it covers the trees, every limb and twig—the trees in the streets, and in the Reservation grounds, are thickly powdered—a deep a coverlid of white snow, everywhere, walks, grou surfaces, roofs, flats, &c.—meanwhile, falling fine and thick, the air full of it—warmish, but not warm enough to melt fast—the sound of the vehicles (Pennsylvania av. by 15th st) muffled by the snow—not the rolling rumble of yesterday—but the army wagons are much less frequent—the blue overcoats of the soldiers serve well now, protecting them with their the capes drawn over their heads, this weather,—a strong, four‑team over
express wagon is wending its way heavily loaded, up the hill on Pennsylvania av above 14th street—the driver shouts to his horses—it is a hard pull through the clotting snow.—all is so I look forth again and again—it is all is so white, so apparitional—not a square foot but has received its deposit—the —I see a lot tent‑shaped trees, evergreens, heavily loaded with snow—the green showing through them a little in a little in places—I stop a long while in the falling drops to look at the beautiful curious show of they the tent‑shaped evergreens make— —I look off toward the Potomac—nothing can be distinguished—the air is too full—the patrol is passing along, their sharp naked bayonets elevated—a contraband woman, bearing balancing a great burden a whole sheet‑full on her head—
—there is the tinkle of the car bells—passengers, domed over protected with the little black, moving domes of umbrellas—the slate‑collalored white‑mottled pigeons, with slanted wings, wheel and sail about in the air, or sink down in momentary squads in the middle of the street, seeking for food—I myself look down from a high, very high window, upon the street, and out on across the white expanse—I see— those black funny mannikins below there, trudging along, slouched, black‑dressed, blue‑dressed, shawled, and or otherwise however enveloped—someway—how they trudge, so slow, so moody they appear, with more or less deprest heads, shuffling along—(whither? to what end ? what is the point of the line, the final use?)does anyone know?)——'car 76 passes, (that is the driver
—beautiful yesterday, I stood on the platform, rode down to the Capitol and back I rode with yesterday, and felt I loved that boy, from the first, and saw he returned it.)—and still as I look the snow is steadily falling.—all is spread so white—the innocent, thick, gigantic coverlid—yesterday the sun shone a brown and variegated earth, all was so soft and balmy, the atmosphere velvet of clearness, and with beams, toned by a transparent haze—now the air is full of thick with these beautiful things, thicker —denser and finer thicker denser they come—the now a white earth, now,,—and nothing else—nothing but that—as if it were going to last—yet in a few hours more, I know what will happen—ephemera! ephemera!—in a few hours—the snows—in a few hours more——(how strangely the simple phrase seizes me, and—

div1.head: sights around Washington—streets
div1.ab:
long trains of army wagons, some with six‑team mules, —some with horses—the teamster astride of the wheel‑horse or walking along by the side, drest in his blue overcoat with his whip over his shoulder—the tinkling bells of the cars, plying toward Georgetown one way, or the Capitol the other—the sight of the unfinished monument, in reservation No 3 ? like an erect bar of soap, slightly tapering, and more than half gone—the strapt officers walking the sidewalks, singly or in groups twos or threes or sometimes in quite big squads—the soldiers, partially recovered from wounds or sickness, limping along with canes or crutches—the contrabands, all sorts, some with the physiognomies of hogs or chimpanzees, others
again, quite as dandified and handsome as any body— —a long train of wood wagons twenty thirty forty of them passing up the avenue, slowly, heavily rumbling, driven by black drivers, the mules straining with their tails out, as it is up hill here. — a The Treasury Building opposite, with its long, costly, absurd collonnade, two hundred feet long, thirty costly columns, darkening all the rooms, and the scrolls on the capitals of the columns. Soldiers sitting around, many on the steps near me sick, half‑sick, feeble, untidy—plenty of improvised sticks to help locomotion—plenty of woe and despair lassitude in their faces—sometimes a look of despair, horrible. Now a long train of lumber ten or twelve stript wagons, with long beams and joists, drawn by four horse teams. More shoulder straps
parading, idly along, many pompous and flippant;—more sick soldiers, with canes, and feebly stepping. More contrabands—A downward train of empty government wagons, going to the river, to be loaded—all —six or seven wagons of them, each with a fine stout teams of four stout grey horses. Where
div1.p: Quite a crowd to‑day on Pennsylvania avenue—ask you —whither bound? ask you? Some to the Capitol—both houses are deep in session, and it draws towards the close of of the term. High themes are up—war, slavery, finance,—many dull edged ae axes wait their anxious grinding. Some wend toward the Departments—the Provost Marshals—Willards—the to some of the scores of paymaster offices.
Now some yellow trimmed cavalry, in big boots, a squad of ten of them, healthy fellows, American faces, from the west.

More shoulder—straps, more acontrabands, more army wagons, many well-drest people, yet all has a scattered, loose look—they have —little or no identity of aggregates here, as in New York, and other great cities I have been in, a carriage, with liveries—some big foreign diplomat or one of the great Secretaries. The city cars, all driven by tidy handsome young American men—the great drivers of the wagons of the big Express lines ditto. Occasionaly some ladies, very richly drest, with children, in furs and feathers—(they p make many now in Washington)

Then Ambulances—not so frequently just here, though there are plenty of them,— hundreds, I don't know but thousands, constantly on the move—but they more generally take the other streets. The ambulance,—now at last then arrived here in our land, domiciliated, a common word, used and understood no at last every where in AThese States—yet that unknown term three years ago an unknown term —but no one is at fault now It iss it very not significant.?

Now goes along a man soldier, young, yet bent over as as he walks just like a capital C. He looks at the numbers, inquiringly—ten to one, the hospital has given him his discharge papers, and he is after his the back pay. (His discharge papers!—the nation has used him to the utmost, short of life, and leaves him with the shape of a capital C. and may‑be eight dollars a month.)

And again more army wagons, f Commissary, lumber, ambulances—more tinkling of car bells, glistening dull glistening of yellow and blue shoulder straps—more contra feeble‑footed, sunken-faced soldiers, —some n ¶The patrol squad, of the guard,, part of the posvosts provost's men, going about, patroling about, examining passes &c ——a sentry , at the door—a cavalry man, on horseback with naked sabre over his shoulder, like a statue at the corner—a great white Aladdin's palace, with an unfinished dome (reported to be cracking) the goddess of Libertymeanwhile standing in the mud with rooms above whose ceilings, float (yearly waiting meanwhile committee rooms) float swarms ethnic goddesses and cupids, painted at three thousand dollars apiece—a long fo thin form, with long sad, dark, deep‑furrowed gentle, face most ugly, most grotesque—haze in the air, a lordly river, a cot? a bloody bandage and a crutch—such are my last my remembrances.

div1.ab: went to day through Wards D. & E. distributing mostly paper & envelopes.—Lewis H. Brown in Ward DE. a most affectionate fellow, very fond of having me come and sit by him—saw the dinner distributed, pretty fair grub—beef. (not too as good as it ought to be)—good soup, puttdding, potatoes &c. —the scene at dinner is quite worth seeing—all who can walk, go out to the general table, those in their beds, who have their dinner brought to them, fare better. In Ward E, a good dinner, well distributed by the excellent woman nurse— (The hospitals ought all to have better diet, better cooked. The bread is always good, and plenty. Never any good tea or coffee)

div1.head: The house corridor
div1.p:
Turning from the main door to the floor, yo for members, you pass through a splendid corridor. I should say as beautiful a piece of interior w finishing as there is in the world—the white ceiling, arched, and simply ornamented, the delicate colors of the tesselated pavement, blue, white, yellow, brownish-yellow, &c—the bronze arched inside window and door frames of bronze, the noble the outer ones of the same, the chandeliers with brilliant lights, (It is at of a night I am standing in it, in a window niche, describing it).
then as you turn to go toward the gallery —the elegant superb and massive marble balustrades and staircase, with the mo columns of mottled brown & white, and the steps of pure white, the hodge‑podge of pictures in the great panel, (a dream masquerade or nightmare dream, of an overland emigrant train crossing the Rocky mountains)—the blue bay of San Francisco frescoed underneath——the whole grandeauur and beautiful proportions and color and m enduring material of this staircase and its area altogether, (I think it the best mod thing I have seen in Washington)—the upper corridors surrounding the gallery, very beautiful, in their tesselated passages
and white walls, divided by green doors and stuck with the marble columns in slight relief—

div1.ab: —the night session, the house is lighted from invisible gas which is itself not visible, except as its powerful jets shines through the astral panels of astral glass overhead—making pouring a broad flood of light down on the members—on over the thick broad surrounding horse shoe of members desks—(saves avoids the odor of gas in the room, so bad to breathe and for the eyes) the clerk is reading some long dull bill,—it is toward the last of the th session (19th Feb. 1863)—it is altogether, the house at night affords a curious scene—the members are idling in their seats—the galleries are full—the clock points to 8—the ladies gallery—in the speakers chair sits the black‑dress'd, thin rather nervous but always prompt speaker of the Congress—the white steps that ascend to it,—and there stand lounging on the steps, talking in an undertone several of the members, and a good‑looking

div1.p: Had an interview with Charles Sumner this morning—I said:
Mr. Sumner, if I don't succeed for the present—dont dont get any thing till the 4th of March, will may I count on your then giving me a boost?"
He said: "Yes, I will—if I can."

Heard Mrs. Swisshelm read an address a statement of the Minnesota massacre by the Indinsans there last fall. It was enough to harrow one's soul. The poetical Indian is all lollypop. The real reds of our northern frontiers, of the present day, are showed have propensities, monstrous and treacherous, that make them unfit to be left in white neighborhood. The details of their murders, mutilations, last fall in Minnesota and many of the the violations of women and children are make as bloody and awful heart‑rending an episode as there is in American history.

One thing in Miss Mrs. Swisshelm's address; I never before yet heard, before a first‑class public audience, (which this was) such plain‑speaking upon matters and things of the body. and It was well done, and well received.

Washington has the deepest and most driving snow‑storm of the season—would be considered a pretty big fall storm even in the north—I write this at noon—I should say the snow is three or four inches thick, with drifts—nobody is out—the expanse looks very, very white—every thing is so ample and open here, it makes a very different appearance, under a snow‑storm, than from the closely crowded old cities—being Sunday, no business, no army wagons, nor bus other vehicles, no pedestrians—a city housed, still, muffled in snow—no sounds hardly a sound breaks the repressed city—yes, there I hear see one sleigh, hear the merry tinkle of the collars of bells on the horses—an a first‑class old‑fashioned yellow sleigh of the for four persons, there they go, trotting cheerfully through the storm, up the avenue.

Spent between from three To‑day from three to four hours in Judiciary Hospital, 1st, 3d & 4th & 5th Wards—distrib gave the men in all those wards paper, envelopes, pens, pencils &c.; also tobacco, quite generally, (ItI think I must have distributed about two pounds in small plugs.) I tTalked with many of the men—wrote a letter f home for Albert Knapp, of Washington Macomb county, Michigan. (hse is in the 102d N N.Y. Vol.)—very sick with pneumonia.
When I came to L. street, to dinner, found Justus Boyd, waiting for me! His papers are through—he is discharged—and expects to leave forthwith for home.

All the elements, capricious, light and shadow, tears and smiles, to‑day. Most of the forenoon was beautiful exceedingly, bright sun, steady and soft atmosphere. At about noon, it grew very dark and cloudy, about 1 it rained—from 2 to 3 we wd had a driving snow‑storm. I never saw the flakes larger—they drove and rampaged away.—very good view from my high window looking across to the Potomac, and Arlington heights, and down to Alexandria. I watched this noble and peculiar storm for an hour—full of fine effects. (When it snows heavily, get into a high place, and look up into the air.) Soon after 3 it began to break. I saw the sun shining over in Old Virginia, away down to toward Fairfax seminary, and and all along shore, for some time while the storm was dark and driving wher all around
where I stood at my high window watching it. Half past 3, it is all clear and bright again—yet almost as I jot this down the clouds come swiftly up. This is the last day of the 37th Congress, the body during whose existence (1861,'2,'3,) the most important, confusing, and abnormal? events in American history, (shall I not say in the history of the world?) have happened. The 37th Congress—as I have watched their debates, (or r wrangles, propositions, personal presences, physiognomies, in their rich and magnificent sky‑lighted halls—gone night and day sat, seen, listened—sometimes almost literally doubting for a moment my own eyes and ears—I have learned much many new things. These then are the men who, do as they do, in the midst of the greatest historic
chaos and gigantic tussle of the greatest of ages.—These Look at the little mannikins, shrewd, gabby, drest in black, hopping about, making motions, amendments,—It is very curious—perhaps aAt night I have liked gone in the gallery to look at them, down there, flooded with light stronger than sunshine, in the most magnificent, and best proportioned rooms in the world—What events are about them, and all of us? Whither are we drifting? Who knows? It seems as if these powerful electric and terrible days were enough to put life and blood in into a paving stone—as if there cou must be a needs come, to form, on the n representative men that have to do with them, an inevitable faces of grandeur, actions of awe, almost clothes of vestments of majesty.

div1.ab:
—the day goes on, a strange, wild, smiling, promising, lowering, spitting, snow‑ day—full of threats and contradictions—black at times as the murkyest eve—then snowing in great flakes, obscuring the air, and with fits of furious driving, and of whirls and eddies around and, around as you look up—then a sharp short shower of rain. It goes on and on—not without gleams, returns of repentance, a fine sky, with sunshine and much promise—but much disquiet too. Then at last, with a long wide
breadth of heavy sombre slate and blacknes opaque le iron or lead in the west, but with a thin belt below it as of clearish crimson crimsonedwater. And there the sun goes down in blood. It seems to me to be looking at these states at these fratricidal states It lingers, not glaring, but astonished, pained, shall I not say terrified—lingers, looks gleams seems to take a indeed to pause and to pierce, out flooding a flood clear, the wonder, the mystery and gr urged chaos of these lands, these days,—but still yet goes down in a flood.
